dollar then we close it for 2 what happened here Prett simple we realized a 100 loss we collected 1 we closed the trade for 2 that means we give up the dollar that we collected up front and then we give up another dollar on top of that that is 100 because obviously you multiply this out by 100 for options this is where the trade lands so where's the roll it's right here if we buy to close at two bucks and then we sell to open at whatever price you've now completed a role common misconception is that roles are only conducted on losing positions you can roll a winning trade it's just in generality and parl when we talk about it it's normally referred to in the context of a losing trade which is actually quite telling when it comes to the mindset of when we roll and this is something I do want to speak about for just a second because it's a common problem people have have is that if this was a winning trade that you closed and then opened you probably wouldn't consider it a role why is that well it's because you're happy with your win that's off the books now we're entering a new trade you don't want to tie the accounting to it because you have a win but when we're rolling very frequently it's fueled by hope we hope this next trade overwhelms the loss of the previous

you're happy with your win that's off the books now we're entering a new trade you don't want to tie the accounting to it because you have a win but when we're rolling very frequently it's fueled by hope we hope this next trade overwhelms the loss of the previous trade so that's why we choose to account it together but again admin note you can roll winning trades as well it's just not commonly done or at least commonly referred to so let's say trade three continues to chug along it goes well and we close that for 50s what's happened here do you know what our realized pl is at this point in this case we takeen 150 bucks we sold this option for two bucks 200 bucks we buy to close it for 50 cents 50 bucks that gives us positive 150 so on this rolled position you will have realized a profit of 50 one of the dangers of rolling is that if you don't close this for the correct price then all of a sudden you can be compounding your loss so for example if you have this 100 realized loss we sell to open this new option for 2 then we buy to close it for 3 what happened in that scenario we realized another 100 loss so your net pl at that point is negative 200 so if you keep going down that path and you don't ever get a price accommodation you

point of doing this a common error Traders make is when they see this option trading for a profit so if this we sold to open for 2 and then now it's trading at 125 you're looking at a 75 profit you're like wow that looks great I want to take that well unfortunately in the net you would have lost money because if you took this down for a 75 profit and you have a 100 realized loss you still lost 25 bucks so you can calculate your rolled options Break Even which is something I definitely recommend tracking I have an Excel sheet that does that which I've thrown into the shop for all the patreon members if you're silver and above you get free access to it it's just a simple tool to help you track things so now if we continue on our best practices what's the best time to roll as you know my answer to this already is it depends there's two things you really need to answer right up front the first thing is what is your objective for the position and the second thing is what do you think about the underlying so let's say you have a position on the best time to roll in terms of getting the highest variability in your strike price is when you are at the money or slightly in the money the reason being is even though there's a bunch of extrinsic value left in

so let's say you have a position on the best time to roll in terms of getting the highest variability in your strike price is when you are at the money or slightly in the money the reason being is even though there's a bunch of extrinsic value left in that option you'll notice you're not moving a bunch of intrinsic value which decreases how effectively you can roll so what this looks like is let's say you were short this 39 put that's now it's in the money right now and it's trading for like 35 36 Cents something like that if we try to roll this and we want to go out one week and we want to collect a credit meaning the rolled trade is bringing in more money than what we're closing if we take a look at that and we know that we need 35 can you get it going further out of the money going out just one week no so we might have to go out let's just pick the next primary expiration you can find you can roll out in time for a credit at the same strike or you can roll out in time and slightly out of the money taking it all the way down to a 28 Delta while collecting a very small credit so when the option price is the same as the strike is when you're going to have the most choices available to you however it's

out in time and slightly out of the money taking it all the way down to a 28 Delta while collecting a very small credit so when the option price is the same as the strike is when you're going to have the most choices available to you however it's also when you're Buy buying back the most extrinsic value so if this is something that you don't mind taking assignment on or don't mind managing in the long run then you can wait a little bit wait for some more of this extrinsic value to bleed out and then you can adjust if this is something that's like leveraged options or you really don't want to take assignment in this case on the short put and you don't want to get stuck what I mean by getting stuck is if you wait until you're too far in the money you get to a point where you actually can't adjust down you can't roll down anymore or if you're on the short calls you can't roll up anymore cuz you're too deep in the money and then you run into another problem which is days to expiration liquidity so for example let's say our option fell in the money the 39s we want to roll out and down cool so we go out and down we have to go to 40 days to be able to roll down now we get our small credit you're a dollar better but let's

why it's a problem because if you roll immediately every time your strike is challenged let's say you're in this 33 days expiration you roll when your strike is challenged then you go to the 40 then you go to the 47 then you go to the 53 then you go to the 75 now you're out out pretty damn far in time data is not ticking away that fast because you're so far out in time and then if you get a continued down move then where do you go you got to 103 days what if the down move continues then you run out of Runway and if the underly continues to move against you you build a really difficult position to move around so when I think about the best time to roll I balance how do I feel about taking the underlying in or out whether I'm short puts or short calls for long or short stock and then I think about what is my disposition towards the underlying because sometimes the best time to roll is never and to take the loss if you're trading something like this let's say you had cash secured puts out on carvana and you were all the way out here you were trading it a while ago when it was 300 bucks and then you're trying to roll your options you're trying to roll your options if you got stuck you're stuck you are there's no rolling your options

out on carvana and you were all the way out here you were trading it a while ago when it was 300 bucks and then you're trying to roll your options you're trying to roll your options if you got stuck you're stuck you are there's no rolling your options from here to here sometimes if you get enough price accommodation in the short term you might be able to get Buy with some of it but big moves that happen quickly can leave you stranded so you have to strongly analyze the underline that you're trading and again the same thing can happen to the inverse if you're one of those real smart contrarian Traders and you know better when the Market's pricing things and you see this big green candle you're like wow I'm going to fade this and smci hasn't come back it's gone from 400 to 579 so in this case you get stuck you need some sort of price accommodation in order to be able to roll and eventually find your way out of the money because the problem is can you roll forever no because if you go back to this original example you are realizing losses if we're rolling a losing trade so when you're rolling a losing trade each time you are eroding your account value sooner or later the margin requirement for your trade is bigger than your account value so even though you might have a bunch of cash sitting
